column1: In a speech in 2011, Mr Johnson said: "All I can ask is that if it were up to me, I would have said: 'Look what these people are doing, let's do this, let's do this'". He later told the Commons he had been told by his deputy mayor, Lord Greenhalgh, to "do what I can to make sure of this". At an election campaign event in April, Mr Johnson promised to end the investigation if it did not result in an outcome that could "strengthen the whole of British democracy". He has refused to commit to any such policies. Mr Johnson is due to speak at the House of Commons on Thursday night. A spokesman for the Commons will not comment on the details of Mr Johnson's comments. But he said: "It is the duty of the committee to investigate the conduct of officials in government, especially government ministers, and to look at the evidence provided to us." If he is found guilty of breaking the laws, Mr Johnson could face a maximum of three years in prison.
'I can't understand my own conscience': Boris Johnson on the law reform bill The former prime minister has repeatedly refused to say how he would react if he were found guilty in the Commons.

I can't understand my own conscience. I can't understand my own conscience, he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "I'm just not going to be involved. I know I have to make my own decision. I am certainly not going to be involved in the debate here. I can't imagine that some people would be so concerned about what I have to say." He said he had been told by his deputy mayor, Lord Greenhalgh, to "do what I can to make sure of this". In his speech, he said: "I think we need to get it right. I think it is an embarrassment that this is being used as a political weapon to smear my reputation."
